ðŸ‘¤ USER â€” 2025-10-21 02:59:44

Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

Result:

     1â†’# Trifle
     2â†’
     3â†’A browser-based Python3 playground where all code execution happens client-side using WebAssembly.
     4â†’
     5â†’## What is Trifle?
     6â†’
     7â†’Trifle is a web application for creating, editing, and running Python3 programs entirely in your browser. Think JSFiddle or CodePen, but for Python, with zero server-side code execution.
     8â†’
     9â†’**Key Features:**
    10â†’- ðŸ Python3 running in browser via [Pyodide](https://pyodide.org/)
    11â†’- ðŸ“ Multiple files per project with folder support
    12â†’- ðŸ’¾ Auto-save as you type
    13â†’- ðŸ” Google OAuth authentication with email allowlist
    14â†’- ðŸŽ­ Victorian-era themed account names (e.g., "dapper-falcon")
    15â†’- ðŸ”’ All code execution is client-side (sandboxed in browser)
    16â†’
    17â†’## Tech Stack
    18â†’
    19â†’- **Backend**: Go 1.25+
    20â†’- **Database**: SQLite with [sqlc](https://sqlc.dev/) and [goose](https://github.com/pressly/goose) migrations
    21â†’- **Frontend**: Vanilla JavaScript, [Ace Editor](https://ace.c9.io/), [Pyodide](https://pyodide.org/)
    22â†’- **Authentication**: Google OAuth 2.0
    23â†’- **Deployment**: Single binary with embedded static files
    24â†’
    25â†’## Running Locally
    26â†’
    27â†’### Prerequisites
    28â†’
    29â†’- Go 1.25 or later
    30â†’- [1Password CLI](https://developer.1password.com/docs/cli/) (for secrets)
    31â†’- Google OAuth credentials (or use the development ones below)
    32â†’
    33â†’### Setup
    34â†’
    35â†’1. Clone the repository:
    36â†’```bash
    37â†’git clone https://github.com/zellyn/trifle.git
    38â†’cd trifle
    39â†’```
    40â†’
    41â†’2. Set environment variables:
    42â†’```bash
    43â†’export GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID="$(op read 'op://Shared/Trifle/Google OAuth Client ID')"
    44â†’export GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET="$(op read 'op://Shared/Trifle/Google OAuth Client Secret')"
    45â†’```
    46â†’
    47â†’3. Run the server:
    48â†’```bash
    49â†’go run main.go
    50â†’```
    51â†’
    52â†’4. Open http://localhost:3000 in your browser
    53â†’
    54â†’### Environment Variables
    55â†’
    56â†’- `GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID` - Google OAuth client ID (required)
    57â†’- `GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET` - Google OAuth client secret (required)
    58â†’- `OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL` - OAuth redirect URL (defaults to `http://localhost:3000/auth/callback`)
    59â†’- `PRODUCTION` - Set to `"true"` to enable secure cookies (for HTTPS)
    60â†’- `PORT` - Server port (defaults to `3000`)
    61â†’
    62â†’## Development
    63â†’
    64â†’### Project Structure
    65â†’
    66â†’```
    67â†’trifle/
    68â†’â”œâ”€â”€ internal/
    69â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ db/          # Database: migrations, queries, manager
    70â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ auth/        # OAuth and session management
    71â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ api/         # HTTP handlers and middleware
    72â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ namegen/     # Account name generator
    73â†’â”œâ”€â”€ web/             # Frontend static files
    74â†’â”œâ”€â”€ main.go          # Entry point
    75â†’â””â”€â”€ sqlc.yaml        # sqlc configuration
    76â†’```
    77â†’
    78â†’### Database
    79â†’
    80â†’Migrations are automatically run on startup. The database is created in `./data/trifle.db`.
    81â†’
    82â†’To regenerate sqlc code after modifying `internal/db/queries.sql`:
    83â†’```bash
    84â†’sqlc generate
    85â†’```
    86â†’
    87â†’### Adding Users to Allowlist
    88â†’
    89â†’Edit `internal/db/migrations/00001_initial_schema.sql` and add entries to the `email_allowlist` table:
    90â†’
    91â†’```sql
    92â†’-- Individual email
    93â†’INSERT INTO email_allowlist (pattern, type) VALUES ('user@example.com', 'email');
    94â†’
    95â†’-- Entire domain
    96â†’INSERT INTO email_allowlist (pattern, type) VALUES ('@example.com', 'domain');
    97â†’```
    98â†’
    99â†’Then delete `./data/trifle.db` and restart to recreate the database.
   100â†’
   101â†’## Current Status
   102â†’
   103â†’**Completed:**
   104â†’- âœ… Google OAuth authentication with allowlist
   105â†’- âœ… Session management
   106â†’- âœ… Database schema and migrations
   107â†’- âœ… Auto-generated account names
   108â†’- âœ… Basic signup/home pages
   109â†’
   110â†’**In Progress:**
   111â†’- ðŸ”² Trifle CRUD API endpoints
   112â†’- ðŸ”² File management API
   113â†’- ðŸ”² Editor frontend
   114â†’- ðŸ”² Pyodide integration
   115â†’
   116â†’See [PLAN.md](PLAN.md) for detailed architecture and roadmap.
   117â†’
   118â†’## License
   119â†’
   120â†’GPLv3
   121â†’

ðŸ¤– ASSISTANT â€” 2025-10-21 03:00:11

Model: claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929 Tokens: 11 in / 1343 out Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

Tool: Write

Input:

{
  "file_path": "/Users/zellyn/gh/trifle/README.md",
  "content": "# Trifle\n\nA local-first browser-based Python3 playground where all code execution happens client-side using WebAssembly.\n\n## What is Trifle?\n\nTrifle is a web application for creating, editing, and running Python3 programs entirely in your browser. Think JSFiddle or CodePen, but for Python, with zero server-side code execution.\n\n**Key Features:**\n- \ud83d\udc0d Python3 running in browser via [Pyodide](https://pyodide.org/)\n- \ud83d\udcdd Multiple files per project with folder support\n- \ud83d\udcbe Auto-save as you type\n- \ud83d\udd0c Works offline (after initial load)\n- \ud83d\udd10 Optional Google OAuth authentication for sync\n- \ud83d\udd12 All code execution is client-side (sandboxed in browser)\n- \ud83d\udcbf Local-first: All data stored in browser IndexedDB\n\n## Tech Stack\n\n- **Backend**: Go 1.25+ (minimal server for OAuth and KV sync)\n- **Storage**: IndexedDB (client-side) + file-based KV store (server-side sync)\n- **Frontend**: Vanilla JavaScript, [Ace Editor](https://ace.c9.io/), [Pyodide](https://pyodide.org/)\n- **Authentication**: Optional Google OAuth 2.0\n- **Deployment**: Single binary with embedded static files\n\n## Running Locally\n\n### Prerequisites\n\n- Go 1.25 or later\n- Google OAuth credentials (optional, only needed for sync)\n\n### Setup\n\n1. Clone the repository:\n```bash\ngit clone https://github.com/zellyn/trifle.git\ncd trifle\n```\n\n2. (Optional) Set environment variables for OAuth:\n```bash\nexport GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID=\"<your-client-id>\"\nexport GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET=\"<your-client-secret>\"\n```\n\n3. Run the server:\n```bash\ngo run main.go\n```\n\n4. Open http://localhost:3000 in your browser\n\n### Environment Variables\n\n- `GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID` - Google OAuth client ID (optional, required for sync)\n- `GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET` - Google OAuth client secret (optional, required for sync)\n- `ADDRESS` - Server address (defaults to `http://localhost:3000`)\n  - Examples: `http://localhost:3000`, `https://trifling.org`\n  - Port and HTTPS are extracted from this address\n  - OAuth redirect URL is automatically set to `{ADDRESS}/auth/callback`\n\n## Development\n\n### Project Structure\n\n```\ntrifle/\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 internal/\n\u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 auth/        # OAuth and session management\n\u2502   \u2514\u2500\u2500 kv/          # File-based key-value store for sync\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 web/             # Frontend static files\n\u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 css/         # Stylesheets\n\u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 js/          # JavaScript modules\n\u2502   \u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 app.js       # Main app controller\n\u2502   \u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 db.js        # IndexedDB storage layer\n\u2502   \u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 editor.js    # Code editor\n\u2502   \u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 sync-kv.js   # Sync manager\n\u2502   \u2502   \u2514\u2500\u2500 ...\n\u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 sw.js        # Service worker for offline support\n\u2502   \u2514\u2500\u2500 *.html       # Page templates\n\u2514\u2500\u2500 main.go          # Entry point\n```\n\n## Architecture\n\nTrifle is a **local-first** application:\n\n- All user data is stored in the browser's IndexedDB\n- Works completely offline after initial page load\n- No account required for basic use\n- Optional sync via Google OAuth:\n  - Server acts as a simple key-value store\n  - Server never parses or executes user code\n  - Conflict resolution via logical clocks\n  - Content-addressed file storage with deduplication\n\n## Current Status\n\n**Completed:**\n- \u2705 IndexedDB storage layer\n- \u2705 Service worker for offline support\n- \u2705 Pyodide integration with web worker execution\n- \u2705 Multi-file editor with auto-save\n- \u2705 ANSI terminal output support\n- \u2705 `input()` support for interactive programs\n- \u2705 Google OAuth authentication (optional)\n- \u2705 Bidirectional sync with KV store\n- \u2705 Profile management with random name generation\n\n**Future Ideas:**\n- \ud83d\udd32 Package installation (pip packages via Pyodide)\n- \ud83d\udd32 Sharing/publishing trifles\n- \ud83d\udd32 Collaborative editing\n- \ud83d\udd32 Version history\n\nSee [PLAN.md](PLAN.md) for detailed architecture and roadmap.\n\n## License\n\nGPLv3\n"
}

     1â†’# Trifle
     2â†’
     3â†’A local-first browser-based Python3 playground where all code execution happens client-side using WebAssembly.
     4â†’
     5â†’## What is Trifle?
     6â†’
     7â†’Trifle is a web application for creating, editing, and running Python3 programs entirely in your browser. Think JSFiddle or CodePen, but for Python, with zero server-side code execution.
     8â†’
     9â†’**Key Features:**
    10â†’- ðŸ Python3 running in browser via [Pyodide](https://pyodide.org/)
    11â†’- ðŸ“ Multiple files per project with folder support
    12â†’- ðŸ’¾ Auto-save as you type
    13â†’- ðŸ”Œ Works offline (after initial load)
    14â†’- ðŸ” Optional Google OAuth authentication for sync
    15â†’- ðŸ”’ All code execution is client-side (sandboxed in browser)
    16â†’- ðŸ’¿ Local-first: All data stored in browser IndexedDB
    17â†’
    18â†’## Tech Stack
    19â†’
    20â†’- **Backend**: Go 1.25+ (minimal server for OAuth and KV sync)
    21â†’- **Storage**: IndexedDB (client-side) + file-based KV store (server-side sync)
    22â†’- **Frontend**: Vanilla JavaScript, [Ace Editor](https://ace.c9.io/), [Pyodide](https://pyodide.org/)
    23â†’- **Authentication**: Optional Google OAuth 2.0
    24â†’- **Deployment**: Single binary with embedded static files
    25â†’
    26â†’## Running Locally
    27â†’
    28â†’### Prerequisites
    29â†’
    30â†’- Go 1.25 or later
    31â†’- Google OAuth credentials (optional, only needed for sync)
    32â†’
    33â†’### Setup
    34â†’
    35â†’1. Clone the repository:
    36â†’```bash
    37â†’git clone https://github.com/zellyn/trifle.git
    38â†’cd trifle
    39â†’```
    40â†’
    41â†’2. (Optional) Set environment variables for OAuth:
    42â†’```bash
    43â†’export GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID="<your-client-id>"
    44â†’export GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET="<your-client-secret>"
    45â†’```
    46â†’
    47â†’3. Run the server:
    48â†’```bash
    49â†’go run main.go
    50â†’```
    51â†’
    52â†’4. Open http://localhost:3000 in your browser
    53â†’
    54â†’### Environment Variables
    55â†’
    56â†’- `GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID` - Google OAuth client ID (optional, required for sync)
    57â†’- `GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET` - Google OAuth client secret (optional, required for sync)
    58â†’- `ADDRESS` - Server address (defaults to `http://localhost:3000`)
    59â†’  - Examples: `http://localhost:3000`, `https://trifling.org`
    60â†’  - Port and HTTPS are extracted from this address
    61â†’  - OAuth redirect URL is automatically set to `{ADDRESS}/auth/callback`
    62â†’
    63â†’## Development
    64â†’
    65â†’### Project Structure
    66â†’
    67â†’```
    68â†’trifle/
    69â†’â”œâ”€â”€ internal/
    70â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ auth/        # OAuth and session management
    71â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ kv/          # File-based key-value store for sync
    72â†’â”œâ”€â”€ web/             # Frontend static files
    73â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ css/         # Stylesheets
    74â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ js/          # JavaScript modules
    75â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ app.js       # Main app controller
    76â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ db.js        # IndexedDB storage layer
    77â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ editor.js    # Code editor
    78â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ sync-kv.js   # Sync manager
    79â†’â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ ...
    80â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ sw.js        # Service worker for offline support
    81â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ *.html       # Page templates
    82â†’â””â”€â”€ main.go          # Entry point
    83â†’```
    84â†’
    85â†’## Architecture
    86â†’
    87â†’Trifle is a **local-first** application:
    88â†’
    89â†’- All user data is stored in the browser's IndexedDB
    90â†’- Works completely offline after initial page load
    91â†’- No account required for basic use
    92â†’- Optional sync via Google OAuth:
    93â†’  - Server acts as a simple key-value store
    94â†’  - Server never parses or executes user code
    95â†’  - Conflict resolution via logical clocks
    96â†’  - Content-addressed file storage with deduplication
    97â†’
    98â†’## Current Status
    99â†’
   100â†’**Completed:**
   101â†’- âœ… IndexedDB storage layer
   102â†’- âœ… Service worker for offline support
   103â†’- âœ… Pyodide integration with web worker execution
   104â†’- âœ… Multi-file editor with auto-save
   105â†’- âœ… ANSI terminal output support
   106â†’- âœ… `input()` support for interactive programs
   107â†’- âœ… Google OAuth authentication (optional)
   108â†’- âœ… Bidirectional sync with KV store

     1â†’package main
     2â†’
     3â†’import (
     4â†’	"context"
     5â†’	"embed"
     6â†’	"fmt"
     7â†’	"io/fs"
     8â†’	"log/slog"
     9â†’	"net/http"
    10â†’	"os"
    11â†’	"os/signal"
    12â†’	"syscall"
    13â†’	"time"
    14â†’
    15â†’	"github.com/zellyn/trifle/internal/auth"
    16â†’	"github.com/zellyn/trifle/internal/kv"
    17â†’)
    18â†’
    19â†’//go:embed web
    20â†’var webFS embed.FS
    21â†’
    22â†’func main() {
    23â†’	// Set up structured logging
    24â†’	logger := slog.New(slog.NewTextHandler(os.Stdout, &slog.HandlerOptions{
    25â†’		Level: slog.LevelInfo,
    26â†’	}))
    27â†’	slog.SetDefault(logger)
    28â†’
    29â†’	// Get port from environment or default to 3000
    30â†’	port := os.Getenv("PORT")
    31â†’	if port == "" {
    32â†’		port = "3000"
    33â†’	}
    34â†’
    35â†’	// Determine if we're in production (HTTPS) or development (HTTP)
    36â†’	isProduction := os.Getenv("PRODUCTION") == "true"
    37â†’
    38â†’	// Data directory for flat-file storage
    39â†’	dataDir := "./data"
    40â†’
    41â†’	// Initialize KV store
    42â†’	kvStore, err := kv.NewStore(dataDir)
    43â†’	if err != nil {
    44â†’		slog.Error("Failed to initialize KV store", "error", err)
    45â†’		os.Exit(1)
    46â†’	}
    47â†’
    48â†’	slog.Info("Storage initialized successfully", "dataDir", dataDir)
    49â†’
    50â†’	// Initialize session manager (for OAuth)
    51â†’	sessionMgr := auth.NewSessionManager(isProduction)
    52â†’
    53â†’	// Get OAuth credentials
    54â†’	clientID, clientSecret, err := auth.GetOAuthCredentials()
    55â†’	if err != nil {
    56â†’		slog.Error("Failed to get OAuth credentials", "error", err)
    57â†’		os.Exit(1)
    58â†’	}
    59â†’
    60â†’	// Determine redirect URL based on environment
    61â†’	redirectURL := os.Getenv("OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL")
    62â†’	if redirectURL == "" {
    63â†’		// Default to localhost if not specified
    64â†’		redirectURL = fmt.Sprintf("http://localhost:%s/auth/callback", port)
    65â†’	}
    66â†’
    67â†’	// Initialize OAuth config
    68â†’	oauthConfig := auth.NewOAuthConfig(clientID, clientSecret, redirectURL, sessionMgr)
    69â†’
    70â†’	// Set up web filesystem
    71â†’	webContent, err := fs.Sub(webFS, "web")
    72â†’	if err != nil {
    73â†’		slog.Error("Failed to get web subdirectory", "error", err)
    74â†’		os.Exit(1)
    75â†’	}
    76â†’
    77â†’	// Set up HTTP router
    78â†’	mux := http.NewServeMux()
    79â†’
    80â†’	// Home page - NO AUTH REQUIRED (local-first!)
    81â†’	// Serves the static index.html which uses IndexedDB
    82â†’	mux.Handle("/", http.FileServer(http.FS(webContent)))
    83â†’
    84â†’	// Auth routes (optional, only for sync)
    85â†’	mux.HandleFunc("/auth/login", oauthConfig.HandleLogin)
    86â†’	mux.HandleFunc("/auth/callback", oauthConfig.HandleCallback)
    87â†’	mux.HandleFunc("/auth/logout", oauthConfig.HandleLogout)
    88â†’	mux.HandleFunc("/api/whoami", auth.HandleWhoAmI(sessionMgr))
    89â†’
    90â†’	// KV API handlers (require authentication)
    91â†’	kvHandlers := kv.NewHandlers(kvStore)
    92â†’
    93â†’	// Create session adapter for KV middleware
    94â†’	kvSessionAdapter := kv.NewSessionManagerAdapter(func(r *http.Request) (string, bool, error) {
    95â†’		session, err := sessionMgr.GetSession(r)
    96â†’		if err != nil {
    97â†’			return "", false, err
    98â†’		}
    99â†’		return session.Email, session.Authenticated, nil
   100â†’	})
   101â†’
   102â†’	requireAuth := kv.RequireAuth(kvSessionAdapter)
   103â†’
   104â†’	// KV endpoints
   105â†’	mux.HandleFunc("/kv/", requireAuth(kvHandlers.HandleKV))
   106â†’	mux.HandleFunc("/kvlist/", requireAuth(kvHandlers.HandleList))
   107â†’
   108â†’	// Serve static files from embedded web directory
   109â†’	mux.Handle("/css/", http.FileServer(http.FS(webContent)))
   110â†’	mux.Handle("/js/", http.FileServer(http.FS(webContent)))
   111â†’
   112â†’	// Create HTTP server with logging middleware
   113â†’	server := &http.Server{
   114â†’		Addr:         fmt.Sprintf(":%s", port),
   115â†’		Handler:      loggingMiddleware(mux),
   116â†’		ReadTimeout:  15 * time.Second,
   117â†’		WriteTimeout: 15 * time.Second,
   118â†’		IdleTimeout:  60 * time.Second,
   119â†’	}
   120â†’
   121â†’	// Start server in goroutine
   122â†’	go func() {
   123â†’		slog.Info("Trifle server starting", "url", fmt.Sprintf("http://localhost:%s", port))
   124â†’		if err := server.ListenAndServe(); err != nil && err != http.ErrServerClosed {
   125â†’			slog.Error("Server failed", "error", err)
   126â†’			os.Exit(1)
   127â†’		}
   128â†’	}()
   129â†’
   130â†’	// Wait for interrupt signal
   131â†’	sigCh := make(chan os.Signal, 1)
   132â†’	signal.Notify(sigCh, syscall.SIGINT, syscall.SIGTERM)
   133â†’	<-sigCh
   134â†’
   135â†’	slog.Info("Shutting down server...")
   136â†’
   137â†’	// Graceful shutdown
   138â†’	ctx, cancel := context.WithTimeout(context.Background(), 15*time.Second)
   139â†’	defer cancel()
   140â†’
   141â†’	if err := server.Shutdown(ctx); err != nil {
   142â†’		slog.Error("Server shutdown error", "error", err)
   143â†’	}
   144â†’
   145â†’	slog.Info("Server stopped")
   146â†’}
   147â†’
   148â†’// loggingMiddleware logs HTTP requests
   149â†’func loggingMiddleware(next http.Handler) http.Handler {
   150â†’	return http.HandlerFunc(func(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
   151â†’		start := time.Now()
   152â†’		next.ServeHTTP(w, r)
   153â†’		duration := time.Since(start)
   154â†’		slog.Info("HTTP request",
   155â†’			"method", r.Method,
   156â†’			"path", r.URL.Path,
   157â†’			"duration", duration,
   158â†’		)
   159â†’	})
   160â†’}
   161â†’

ðŸ¤– ASSISTANT â€” 2025-10-21 03:01:11

Model: claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929 Tokens: 11 in / 3 out Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

ðŸ’­ Thinking

I need to refactor main.go to parse the ADDRESS environment variable. The ADDRESS should be something like:

  • http://localhost:3000 (default)
  • https://trifling.org

From this, I need to extract:

  1. Scheme (http vs https) - to determine isProduction
  2. Host - for the listen address
  3. Port - for the listen address
  4. Full URL - to construct redirectURL

I'll need to use net/url to parse this properly.

Let me write the refactored version:

// Get server address from environment or default
address := os.Getenv("ADDRESS")
if address == "" {
    address = "http://localhost:3000"
}

// Parse the address URL
addressURL, err := url.Parse(address)
if err != nil {
    slog.Error("Invalid ADDRESS", "address", address, "error", err)
    os.Exit(1)
}

// Determine if we're in production (HTTPS)
isProduction := addressURL.Scheme == "https"

// Extract port from URL
port := addressURL.Port()
if port == "" {
    if isProduction {
        port = "443"
    } else {
        port = "80"
    }
}

// Construct redirect URL
redirectURL := address + "/auth/callback"

Wait, I also need to consider that the server binds to a port, not a full URL. So if ADDRESS is https://trifling.org, the server should bind to :443, but we can't do that without root. Let me think about this differently.

Actually, looking at the code, the server always binds to :{port}. So if ADDRESS is https://trifling.org, we should extract the port (default 443), but in practice for a production deployment behind a reverse proxy, we'd probably still want to bind to a different port like 8080.

I recognize the need to distinguish between external and internal server configurations. The ADDRESS represents the external URL users access, while the server binding might differ based on deployment environment.

Key considerations emerge:

  • Development scenarios typically use direct localhost binding
  • Production setups often involve reverse proxies or load balancers
  • We need flexibility in port configuration
  • The external URL matters for OAuth redirect purposes

The approach should support:

  1. Parsing the external address
  2. Determining production status via scheme
  3. Allowing flexible internal port binding
  4. Maintaining correct redirect URL generation

I'll focus on creating a robust configuration mechanism that adapts to different deployment scenarios while keeping the code clean and configurable. I'll extract the port from the address URL, defaulting to a non-privileged port if no explicit port is specified. For production HTTPS deployments, running behind a reverse proxy is common, so using a standard non-root port like 8080 makes sense. The code parses the address, determines the appropriate port, and prepares to construct the redirect URL.

The approach handles different scenarios elegantly: local development with explicit ports, production HTTPS with proxy forwarding, and custom port configurations. It provides flexibility while maintaining a clean, consistent method for setting up OAuth callback redirects.

ðŸ‘¤ USER â€” 2025-10-21 03:01:33

Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

Result:

     1â†’# Trifle - Project Context for Claude
     2â†’
     3â†’## What This Is
     4â†’Browser-based Python3 playground using Pyodide (WASM). All code execution happens client-side in the browser. Google OAuth with email allowlist controls access.
     5â†’
     6â†’## Current Status
     7â†’**Completed:** Phases 1-3 (Foundation, Auth, Backend API)
     8â†’- Database, migrations, ID generation, name generator
     9â†’- Google OAuth flow, allowlist, sessions, auto-account creation
    10â†’- Full REST API for trifles and files (CRUD, batch updates)
    11â†’- Account name suggestion & validation system
    12â†’- HTML templates (signup, home with trifle list, editor structure)
    13â†’
    14â†’**In Progress:** Phases 4-6 - Frontend (editor JS, Pyodide integration)
    15â†’
    16â†’**Run locally:**
    17â†’```bash
    18â†’export GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID="$(op read 'op://Shared/Trifle/Google OAuth Client ID')"
    19â†’export GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET="$(op read 'op://Shared/Trifle/Google OAuth Client Secret')"
    20â†’go run main.go  # â†’ http://localhost:3000
    21â†’```
    22â†’
    23â†’**Key decisions:**
    24â†’- Session cleanup on login (not background goroutine)
    25â†’- Context cancellation in DB
    26â†’- **SameSite=Lax** (not Strict) for OAuth callback compatibility
    27â†’- Trifle IDs=16 hex chars
    28â†’- Templates loaded from embedded FS (not inline)
    29â†’- Client-side execution = **works offline** (after initial load)
    30â†’- Graceful offline handling (shows "Offline" instead of error popups)
    31â†’
    32â†’## Module Organization
    33â†’- `internal/db/` - SQLite schema, sqlc queries, single-goroutine manager pattern, ID generation
    34â†’- `internal/auth/` - Google OAuth, sessions, allowlist checking
    35â†’- `internal/api/` - HTTP handlers, endpoints, middleware (auth, CSRF)
    36â†’- `internal/namegen/` - Adjective-noun account name generator
    37â†’- `web/` - Static frontend (Ace editor, Pyodide, vanilla JS)
    38â†’  - `editor.js` - File tree, auto-save, Pyodide execution, `input()` support, ANSI color parsing
    39â†’
    40â†’## Python Features
    41â†’
    42â†’**`input()` Support**: Terminal-style input directly in the console (like real Python REPL)
    43â†’- Type appears in the console as you enter it
    44â†’- Press Enter to submit
    45â†’- Works for classroom scenarios (guess-the-number, interactive programs, etc.)
    46â†’```python
    47â†’name = input("What's your name? ")
    48â†’print(f"Hello, {name}!")
    49â†’```
    50â†’
    51â†’**ANSI Color Codes**: Full support for terminal colors and backgrounds
    52â†’```python
    53â†’print('\x1b[31mRed text\x1b[0m')
    54â†’print('\x1b[32;40mGreen on black\x1b[0m')
    55â†’```
    56â†’
    57â†’Supported codes: 30-37 (foreground), 40-47 (background), 49 (bg default), 0 (reset)
    58â†’
    59â†’## Editor Shortcuts
    60â†’
    61â†’- **Cmd+Enter** (Mac) / **Ctrl+Enter** (Windows/Linux) - Run code
    62â†’- Auto-save after 1 second of typing inactivity
    63â†’
    64â†’## Workflow
    65â†’
    66â†’**Before committing**: Always use Task tool to launch a code review agent to check for issues.
    67â†’
    68â†’## Critical: SQLite Dependency
    69â†’`modernc.org/sqlite` and `modernc.org/libc` versions **must match exactly** (see go.mod comment). Test enforces this: `go test ./internal/db`. Never upgrade one without the other.
    70â†’
    71â†’---
    72â†’
    73â†’**IMPORTANT FOR CLAUDE**: When you notice information in conversations that either:
    74â†’1. Contradicts something in this file, OR
    75â†’2. Seems important enough to add (architectural decisions, gotchas, invariants)
    76â†’
    77â†’â†’ Start a conversation with the user about updating CLAUDE.md. Keep it high-value and succinct.
    78â†’

{
  "file_path": "/Users/zellyn/gh/trifle/CLAUDE.md",
  "content": "# Trifle - Project Context for Claude\n\n## What This Is\nLocal-first browser-based Python3 playground using Pyodide (WASM). All code execution happens client-side. Optional Google OAuth for syncing data to server.\n\n## Current Status\n**Completed:**\n- \u2705 IndexedDB storage layer (client-side)\n- \u2705 Service worker for offline support\n- \u2705 Pyodide integration with web worker execution\n- \u2705 Multi-file editor with auto-save\n- \u2705 ANSI terminal output support\n- \u2705 `input()` support for interactive programs\n- \u2705 Google OAuth authentication (optional, for sync)\n- \u2705 Bidirectional sync with file-based KV store\n- \u2705 Profile management with random name generation\n\n**Run locally:**\n```bash\nexport GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID=\"$(op read 'op://Shared/Trifle/Google OAuth Client ID')\"\nexport GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET=\"$(op read 'op://Shared/Trifle/Google OAuth Client Secret')\"\ngo run main.go  # \u2192 http://localhost:3000\n```\n\n**Key decisions:**\n- **Local-first**: All data in browser IndexedDB, no account required\n- **Optional sync**: Google OAuth only needed for backup/restore\n- **Pure KV store**: Server never parses user data, just stores opaque bytes\n- **Content-addressed storage**: Files stored by SHA-256 hash for deduplication\n- **Logical clocks**: Conflict resolution for bidirectional sync\n- **SameSite=Lax** (not Strict) for OAuth callback compatibility\n- **ADDRESS env var**: Single variable for scheme, host, port (e.g., `http://localhost:3000` or `https://trifling.org`)\n- Client-side execution = **works offline** (after initial load)\n- Graceful offline handling (service worker shows \"Offline\" page)\n\n## Module Organization\n- `internal/auth/` - Google OAuth, sessions (email-based, no DB)\n- `internal/kv/` - File-based key-value store for sync\n- `web/` - Static frontend (Ace editor, Pyodide, vanilla JS)\n  - `js/app.js` - Main app controller, trifle list, modals\n  - `js/db.js` - IndexedDB storage layer with content addressing\n  - `js/editor.js` - File tree, auto-save, Pyodide execution, `input()` support, ANSI color parsing\n  - `js/sync-kv.js` - Bidirectional sync manager\n  - `js/namegen.js` - Client-side random name generator\n  - `sw.js` - Service worker for offline support\n\n## Python Features\n\n**`input()` Support**: Terminal-style input directly in the console (like real Python REPL)\n- Type appears in the console as you enter it\n- Press Enter to submit\n- Works for classroom scenarios (guess-the-number, interactive programs, etc.)\n```python\nname = input(\"What's your name? \")\nprint(f\"Hello, {name}!\")\n```\n\n**ANSI Color Codes**: Full support for terminal colors and backgrounds\n```python\nprint('\\x1b[31mRed text\\x1b[0m')\nprint('\\x1b[32;40mGreen on black\\x1b[0m')\n```\n\nSupported codes: 30-37 (foreground), 40-47 (background), 49 (bg default), 0 (reset)\n\n## Editor Shortcuts\n\n- **Cmd+Enter** (Mac) / **Ctrl+Enter** (Windows/Linux) - Run code\n- Auto-save after 1 second of typing inactivity\n\n## Modal UX\n\nNew Trifle modal:\n- Auto-focuses title field\n- **Cmd/Ctrl+Enter** to submit\n- **Esc** to cancel\n\n## Workflow\n\n**Before committing**: Always use Task tool to launch a code review agent to check for issues.\n\n## KV Sync Schema\n\nServer stores user data in flat files:\n```\ndata/\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 user/{email}/profile                              # User profile JSON\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 user/{email}/trifle/latest/{trifle_id}/{version}  # Latest version pointer (empty file)\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 user/{email}/trifle/version/{version}             # Version metadata with file refs\n\u2514\u2500\u2500 file/{hash[0:2]}/{hash[2:4]}/{hash}               # Content-addressed files (global)\n```\n\n- Email-based access control (user can only access their own data)\n- `file/*` is global (content-addressed, anyone can read/write)\n- Version ID = `version_{hash[0:16]}`\n\n---\n\n**IMPORTANT FOR CLAUDE**: When you notice information in conversations that either:\n1. Contradicts something in this file, OR\n2. Seems important enough to add (architectural decisions, gotchas, invariants)\n\n\u2192 Start a conversation with the user about updating CLAUDE.md. Keep it high-value and succinct.\n"
}

     1â†’# Trifle - Project Context for Claude
     2â†’
     3â†’## What This Is
     4â†’Local-first browser-based Python3 playground using Pyodide (WASM). All code execution happens client-side. Optional Google OAuth for syncing data to server.
     5â†’
     6â†’## Current Status
     7â†’**Completed:**
     8â†’- âœ… IndexedDB storage layer (client-side)
     9â†’- âœ… Service worker for offline support
    10â†’- âœ… Pyodide integration with web worker execution
    11â†’- âœ… Multi-file editor with auto-save
    12â†’- âœ… ANSI terminal output support
    13â†’- âœ… `input()` support for interactive programs
    14â†’- âœ… Google OAuth authentication (optional, for sync)
    15â†’- âœ… Bidirectional sync with file-based KV store
    16â†’- âœ… Profile management with random name generation
    17â†’
    18â†’**Run locally:**
    19â†’```bash
    20â†’export GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID="$(op read 'op://Shared/Trifle/Google OAuth Client ID')"
    21â†’export GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET="$(op read 'op://Shared/Trifle/Google OAuth Client Secret')"
    22â†’go run main.go  # â†’ http://localhost:3000
    23â†’```
    24â†’
    25â†’**Key decisions:**
    26â†’- **Local-first**: All data in browser IndexedDB, no account required
    27â†’- **Optional sync**: Google OAuth only needed for backup/restore
    28â†’- **Pure KV store**: Server never parses user data, just stores opaque bytes
    29â†’- **Content-addressed storage**: Files stored by SHA-256 hash for deduplication
    30â†’- **Logical clocks**: Conflict resolution for bidirectional sync
    31â†’- **SameSite=Lax** (not Strict) for OAuth callback compatibility
    32â†’- **ADDRESS env var**: Single variable for scheme, host, port (e.g., `http://localhost:3000` or `https://trifling.org`)

    34â†’- Graceful offline handling (service worker shows "Offline" page)
    35â†’

    40â†’  - `js/app.js` - Main app controller, trifle list, modals

    49â†’**`input()` Support**: Terminal-style input directly in the console (like real Python REPL)
    50â†’- Type appears in the console as you enter it

    54â†’name = input("What's your name? ")
    55â†’print(f"Hello, {name}!")
    56â†’```

    60â†’print('\x1b[31mRed text\x1b[0m')
    61â†’print('\x1b[32;40mGreen on black\x1b[0m')

    86â†’data/
    87â†’â”œâ”€â”€ user/{email}/profile                              # User profile JSON

ðŸ‘¤ USER â€” 2025-10-21 03:05:19

A quick question. My plan is to run this behind Caddy, and have Caddy terminate TLS. So the address will be https://trifling.org, but the server will still need to listen on some port. Should we add PORT in addition to ADDRESS?

Actually... maybe you had the right idea before. Does anything in the code actually reference the domain or build non-relative URLs? Maybe OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL was the right idea all along?

ðŸ¤– ASSISTANT â€” 2025-10-21 03:05:33

Model: claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929 Tokens: 9 in / 6 out Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

ðŸ’­ Thinking

The user is asking a good question. Let me think about where the server actually needs to know the full public address vs just the port to bind to.

Looking at the code:

  1. The server binds to a port (currently extracted from ADDRESS)
  2. OAuth needs the redirect URL (currently built from ADDRESS + "/auth/callback")

Does anything else reference the domain? Let me check:

  • The server just serves files and handles requests
  • The OAuth redirect URL is the only place where we need the full public URL
  • Everything else is handled client-side or with relative URLs

So the user is right - we probably only need:

  • PORT (or extract from ADDRESS) for binding
  • OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL for OAuth

Actually, thinking about the deployment scenario:

  • Caddy terminates TLS at https://trifling.org
  • Caddy proxies to http://localhost:3000 (or whatever port)
  • The server only needs to know what port to bind to
  • The OAuth redirect URL needs to be the public URL: https://trifling.org/auth/callback

So we have two options:

  1. Go back to PORT + OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL (separate concerns)
  2. Keep ADDRESS but still have PORT override

I think option 1 is cleaner and more explicit. The server doesn't need to know its public address except for OAuth.

Also, I should note that currently we extract isProduction from the scheme, but that's only used for secure cookies. If we're behind a reverse proxy, we might want to set that based on the OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL scheme, or have a separate PRODUCTION flag again, or infer it from the redirect URL.

Let me suggest going back to the simpler approach: PORT and OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL.

ðŸ¤– ASSISTANT â€” 2025-10-21 03:05:36

Model: claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929 Tokens: 9 in / 6 out Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

You're absolutely right! Let me think through what the server actually needs to know:

  1. What port to bind to - For the server to listen (e.g., 3000)
  2. OAuth redirect URL - For Google OAuth (e.g., https://trifling.org/auth/callback)

Everything else is client-side with relative URLs. The server doesn't need to know its public domain except for OAuth.

So yes, I think PORT + OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL is the cleaner approach:

  • PORT defaults to 3000
  • OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL is required for OAuth (e.g., https://trifling.org/auth/callback)
  • We can infer isProduction (secure cookies) from the redirect URL scheme

This is more explicit and separates concerns. Should I revert to that approach?

The user wants me to revert to the PORT + OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL approach. Let me update main.go to:

  1. Use PORT env var (default 3000)
  2. Use OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL env var (default http://localhost:{PORT}/auth/callback)
  3. Infer isProduction from the redirect URL scheme (https = production)

This is cleaner and more explicit about what the server needs to know.

}

    25â†’**Key decisions:**
    26â†’- **Local-first**: All data in browser IndexedDB, no account required
    27â†’- **Optional sync**: Google OAuth only needed for backup/restore
    28â†’- **Pure KV store**: Server never parses user data, just stores opaque bytes
    29â†’- **Content-addressed storage**: Files stored by SHA-256 hash for deduplication
    30â†’- **Logical clocks**: Conflict resolution for bidirectional sync
    31â†’- **SameSite=Lax** (not Strict) for OAuth callback compatibility
    32â†’- **Production detection**: Inferred from OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL scheme (https = secure cookies)
    33â†’- Client-side execution = **works offline** (after initial load)
    34â†’- Graceful offline handling (service worker shows "Offline" page)

    38â†’- `internal/kv/` - File-based key-value store for sync

ðŸ¤– ASSISTANT â€” 2025-10-21 03:07:02

Model: claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929 Tokens: 9 in / 2 out Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

Excellent! All changes complete and tested. Here's what I did:

Reverted to PORT + OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL approach:

  1. main.go:

    • PORT env var (defaults to 3000) - what port to bind to
    • OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL env var (defaults to http://localhost:{PORT}/auth/callback)
    • isProduction inferred from redirect URL scheme (https:// = secure cookies)

  2. README.md: Updated environment variables section with clear examples

  3. CLAUDE.md: Updated key decisions to reflect production detection approach

For your Caddy setup, you'll run:

export PORT=3000
export OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL="https://trifling.org/auth/callback"
export GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID="..."
export GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET="..."
go run main.go

The server will:

  • Bind to port 3000 (localhost)
  • Use secure cookies (because redirect URL is https)
  • Caddy handles TLS termination and proxies to localhost:3000

Ready to commit these changes?

Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

yes!

ðŸ‘¤ USER â€” 2025-10-22 05:20:59

Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

I'm having trouble accessing WebAssembly (and SharedArrayBuffer when testing), but only on my work laptop and only in Chrome

Claude thinks maybe we need: Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy: same-origin Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy: require-corp

Does that seem plausible?

ðŸ¤– ASSISTANT â€” 2025-10-22 05:21:10

Model: claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929 Tokens: 9 in / 8 out Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

ðŸ’­ Thinking

The user is having trouble accessing WebAssembly and SharedArrayBuffer but only on their work laptop and only in Chrome. Claude (I assume another instance or conversation) suggested adding these headers:

  • Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy: same-origin
  • Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy: require-corp

This is actually a very plausible explanation! SharedArrayBuffer was disabled in browsers after the Spectre/Meltdown vulnerabilities, and browsers now require these COOP/COEP headers to re-enable it for security reasons.

Pyodide can use SharedArrayBuffer for better performance, though it should also work without it (just slower). However, the fact that WebAssembly itself isn't accessible is a bit odd - WebAssembly should work without these headers.

But if it's only happening on the work laptop in Chrome, it could be:

  1. Corporate proxy/firewall stripping headers
  2. Chrome enterprise policies
  3. Missing COOP/COEP headers (which are required for SharedArrayBuffer and some advanced WebAssembly features)

Adding these headers is a good practice for Pyodide applications anyway, as they enable full performance. The headers tell the browser "this page is isolated enough to safely enable SharedArrayBuffer".

Let me help them add these headers to the Go server.

ðŸ¤– ASSISTANT â€” 2025-10-22 05:21:12

Model: claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929 Tokens: 9 in / 8 out Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

Yes, that's very plausible! SharedArrayBuffer requires those headers for security reasons (post-Spectre/Meltdown). Pyodide performs better with SharedArrayBuffer enabled.

Those headers are:

  • Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy: same-origin - Isolates the browsing context
  • Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy: require-corp - Ensures all resources are explicitly allowed

Let me add a middleware to set these headers:

ðŸ¤– ASSISTANT â€” 2025-10-22 05:21:17

Model: claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929 Tokens: 9 in / 8 out Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

Tool: Edit

Input:

{
  "file_path": "/Users/zellyn/gh/trifle/main.go",
  "old_string": "// loggingMiddleware logs HTTP requests\nfunc loggingMiddleware(next http.Handler) http.Handler {\n\treturn http.HandlerFunc(func(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {\n\t\tstart := time.Now()\n\t\tnext.ServeHTTP(w, r)\n\t\tduration := time.Since(start)\n\t\tslog.Info(\"HTTP request\",\n\t\t\t\"method\", r.Method,\n\t\t\t\"path\", r.URL.Path,\n\t\t\t\"duration\", duration,\n\t\t)\n\t})\n}",
  "new_string": "// loggingMiddleware logs HTTP requests\nfunc loggingMiddleware(next http.Handler) http.Handler {\n\treturn http.HandlerFunc(func(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {\n\t\tstart := time.Now()\n\t\tnext.ServeHTTP(w, r)\n\t\tduration := time.Since(start)\n\t\tslog.Info(\"HTTP request\",\n\t\t\t\"method\", r.Method,\n\t\t\t\"path\", r.URL.Path,\n\t\t\t\"duration\", duration,\n\t\t)\n\t})\n}\n\n// securityHeadersMiddleware adds security headers for WebAssembly/SharedArrayBuffer\nfunc securityHeadersMiddleware(next http.Handler) http.Handler {\n\treturn http.HandlerFunc(func(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {\n\t\t// Required for SharedArrayBuffer (used by Pyodide for better performance)\n\t\tw.Header().Set(\"Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy\", \"same-origin\")\n\t\tw.Header().Set(\"Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy\", \"require-corp\")\n\t\tnext.ServeHTTP(w, r)\n\t})\n}"
}

The file /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle/main.go has been updated. Here's the result of running `cat -n` on a snippet of the edited file:
   145â†’
   146â†’	slog.Info("Server stopped")
   147â†’}
   148â†’
   149â†’// loggingMiddleware logs HTTP requests
   150â†’func loggingMiddleware(next http.Handler) http.Handler {
   151â†’	return http.HandlerFunc(func(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
   152â†’		start := time.Now()
   153â†’		next.ServeHTTP(w, r)
   154â†’		duration := time.Since(start)
   155â†’		slog.Info("HTTP request",
   156â†’			"method", r.Method,
   157â†’			"path", r.URL.Path,
   158â†’			"duration", duration,
   159â†’		)
   160â†’	})
   161â†’}
   162â†’
   163â†’// securityHeadersMiddleware adds security headers for WebAssembly/SharedArrayBuffer
   164â†’func securityHeadersMiddleware(next http.Handler) http.Handler {
   165â†’	return http.HandlerFunc(func(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
   166â†’		// Required for SharedArrayBuffer (used by Pyodide for better performance)
   167â†’		w.Header().Set("Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy", "same-origin")
   168â†’		w.Header().Set("Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy", "require-corp")
   169â†’		next.ServeHTTP(w, r)
   170â†’	})
   171â†’}
   172â†’

  1. ðŸ¤– ASSISTANT â€” 2025-10-22 14:51:00

Model: claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929 Tokens: 9 in / 2 out Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

ðŸ’­ Thinking

Two bugs to fix:

  1. Service worker caching issue: When creating a new trifle offline, the URL is editor.html?id=trifle_ce6c69ad4619 but the service worker can't find it because it's trying to fetch the exact URL with query parameters. The service worker should strip query parameters when matching against the cache.

  2. WebAssembly not available: Need to detect when WebAssembly is disabled and show a helpful error message instead of the spinner hanging forever.

Let me fix both:

Fix 1: Service Worker Query Parameter Handling

The service worker needs to strip query parameters when matching cached files. The issue is that we cache /editor.html but try to fetch /editor.html?id=....

Fix 2: WebAssembly Detection

Need to add a check in the editor initialization to detect if WebAssembly is available and show a helpful error message.

Let me start with the service worker fix.

ðŸ¤– ASSISTANT â€” 2025-10-22 14:51:01

ðŸ‘¤ USER â€” 2025-10-22 14:51:01

Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

Result:

    82â†’// Fetch event - serve from cache, fallback to network
    83â†’self.addEventListener('fetch', (event) => {
    84â†’    // Skip non-GET requests
    85â†’    if (event.request.method !== 'GET') {
    86â†’        return;
    87â†’    }
    88â†’
    89â†’    const url = new URL(event.request.url);
    90â†’
    91â†’    // NEVER cache API endpoints - they need fresh data
    92â†’    if (url.pathname.startsWith('/api/')) {
    93â†’        return; // Let it go to network
    94â†’    }
    95â†’
    96â†’    event.respondWith(
    97â†’        caches.match(event.request).then((cachedResponse) => {
    98â†’            if (cachedResponse) {
    99â†’                console.log('[Service Worker] Serving from cache:', event.request.url);
   100â†’                return cachedResponse;
   101â†’            }
   102â†’
   103â†’            // Not in cache, fetch from network
   104â†’            console.log('[Service Worker] Fetching from network:', event.request.url);
   105â†’            return fetch(event.request).then((response) => {
   106â†’                // Don't cache if not a valid response
   107â†’                if (!response || response.status !== 200 || response.type === 'error') {
   108â†’                    return response;
   109â†’                }
   110â†’
   111â†’                // Clone the response (can only be consumed once)
   112â†’                const responseToCache = response.clone();
   113â†’
   114â†’                // Cache the response for future use (but not API endpoints)
   115â†’                if (!url.pathname.startsWith('/api/')) {
   116â†’                    caches.open(CACHE_NAME).then((cache) => {
   117â†’                        cache.put(event.request, responseToCache);
   118â†’                    });
   119â†’                }
   120â†’
   121â†’                return response;
   122â†’            }).catch((err) => {
   123â†’                console.error('[Service Worker] Fetch failed:', event.request.url, err);
   124â†’
   125â†’                // If it's a navigation request and we're offline, show a friendly message
   126â†’                if (event.request.mode === 'navigate') {
   127â†’                    return new Response(
   128â†’                        '<html><body><h1>Offline</h1><p>You are offline and this page is not cached.</p></body></html>',
   129â†’                        { headers: { 'Content-Type': 'text/html' } }
   130â†’                    );
   131â†’                }
   132â†’
   133â†’                throw err;
   134â†’            });
   135â†’        })
   136â†’    );
   137â†’});
   138â†’
   139â†’// Message event - handle commands from the page
   140â†’self.addEventListener('message', (event) => {
   141â†’    if (event.data && event.data.type === 'SKIP_WAITING') {

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it looks malicious. If it does, you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer high-level questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

ðŸ¤– ASSISTANT â€” 2025-10-22 14:51:07

Model: claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929 Tokens: 11 in / 2 out Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

ðŸ’­ Thinking

I need to fix the service worker to strip query parameters when matching against the cache. The issue is that we cache /editor.html but the request is for /editor.html?id=trifle_ce6c69ad4619.

I'll modify the fetch event handler to:

  1. First try to match the exact request
  2. If that fails and there are query parameters, try to match without query parameters
  3. Only then fall back to the network

ðŸ‘¤ USER â€” 2025-10-22 14:51:15

    93â†’        return; // Let it go to network
    94â†’    }

    96â†’    event.respondWith(
    97â†’        caches.match(event.request).then((cachedResponse) => {
    98â†’            if (cachedResponse) {
    99â†’                console.log('[Service Worker] Serving from cache:', event.request.url);
   100â†’                return cachedResponse;
   101â†’            }
   102â†’
   103â†’            // If not found and URL has query params, try without them
   104â†’            if (url.search) {
   105â†’                const urlWithoutQuery = new URL(url.pathname, url.origin);
   106â†’                return caches.match(urlWithoutQuery).then((cachedResponseNoQuery) => {
   107â†’                    if (cachedResponseNoQuery) {
   108â†’                        console.log('[Service Worker] Serving from cache (no query):', url.pathname);
   109â†’                        return cachedResponseNoQuery;
   110â†’                    }
   111â†’
   112â†’                    // Not in cache, fetch from network
   113â†’                    return fetchFromNetwork();
   114â†’                });
   115â†’            }
   116â†’
   117â†’            // Not in cache, fetch from network
   118â†’            return fetchFromNetwork();
   119â†’        })
   120â†’    );
   121â†’
   122â†’    function fetchFromNetwork() {
   123â†’        console.log('[Service Worker] Fetching from network:', event.request.url);
   124â†’        return fetch(event.request).then((response) => {
   125â†’                // Don't cache if not a valid response
   126â†’                if (!response || response.status !== 200 || response.type === 'error') {
   127â†’                    return response;
   128â†’                }

    39â†’
    40â†’// Canvas management
    41â†’function updateOutputLayout() {
    42â†’    const outputContent = document.getElementById('outputContent');
    43â†’    const canvasPane = document.getElementById('canvasPane');
    44â†’    const popoutBtn = document.getElementById('popoutCanvasBtn');
    45â†’
    46â†’    // Remove all layout classes
    47â†’    outputContent.classList.remove('console-only', 'canvas-only', 'split');
    48â†’
    49â†’    if (state.canvasUsed && state.consoleUsed) {
    50â†’        // Both used: show split view
    51â†’        outputContent.classList.add('split');
    52â†’        canvasPane.style.display = 'flex';
    53â†’        popoutBtn.style.display = 'inline-block';
    54â†’    } else if (state.canvasUsed) {
    55â†’        // Only canvas: show canvas only
    56â†’        outputContent.classList.add('canvas-only');
    57â†’        canvasPane.style.display = 'flex';
    58â†’        popoutBtn.style.display = 'inline-block';
    59â†’    } else {
    60â†’        // Only console (or neither): show console only
    61â†’        outputContent.classList.add('console-only');
    62â†’        canvasPane.style.display = 'none';
    63â†’        popoutBtn.style.display = 'none';
    64â†’    }
    65â†’}
    66â†’
    67â†’function markCanvasUsed() {
    68â†’    state.canvasUsed = true;
    69â†’    updateOutputLayout();
    70â†’}
    71â†’
    72â†’function markConsoleUsed() {
    73â†’    if (!state.consoleUsed) {
    74â†’        state.consoleUsed = true;
    75â†’        updateOutputLayout();
    76â†’    }
    77â†’}
    78â†’
    79â†’function clearOutput() {

    89â†’    state.canvasUsed = false;
    90â†’    state.consoleUsed = false;

ðŸ¤– ASSISTANT â€” 2025-10-22 14:52:21

Model: claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929 Tokens: 3 in / 6 out Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

ðŸ’­ Thinking

ðŸ¤– ASSISTANT â€” 2025-10-22 14:52:29

Model: claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929 Tokens: 3 in / 6 out Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

Perfect! I've fixed both issues:

Fix 1: Service Worker Query Parameter Handling

Problem: When creating a trifle offline, the URL like /editor.html?id=trifle_ce6c69ad4619 wasn't being matched against the cached /editor.html.

Solution: Modified the service worker to strip query parameters when looking for cached resources:

  1. First tries to match the exact request
  2. If not found and there are query parameters, tries again without them
  3. Only then falls back to network

Changes: Updated web/sw.js (cache version bumped to v15)

Fix 2: WebAssembly Detection

Problem: When WebAssembly is disabled (common in enterprise Chrome), the editor would show an infinite spinner with only console errors.

Solution: Added WebAssembly detection at the start of editor initialization with a helpful error message explaining:

  • Why WebAssembly is needed
  • Common reasons it might be unavailable
  • What to try (different browser, check settings, contact IT)

Changes: Updated web/js/editor.js

Both fixes are ready to test. The service worker will automatically update on next page load, and the WebAssembly check will show a user-friendly alert before the editor even tries to load.

Ready to commit?

ðŸ¤– ASSISTANT â€” 2025-10-22 15:00:05

Model: claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929 Tokens: 9 in / 2 out Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

ðŸ’­ Thinking

Let me review what we learned in this session and what's currently in CLAUDE.md:

Current CLAUDE.md includes:

  • Local-first architecture description
  • Status of what's completed
  • Key decisions (local-first, KV store, logical clocks, etc.)
  • Module organization
  • Python features (input(), ANSI colors)
  • Editor shortcuts
  • Modal UX
  • KV sync schema
  • Workflow (code review before commits)

Things learned in this session:

  1. Service worker query parameter handling - URLs with query params should fall back to base URL
  2. WebAssembly detection is needed for helpful error messages
  3. Environment variable preferences: PORT + OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL (not ADDRESS)
  4. Production mode inferred from OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL scheme
  5. Server is designed to run behind reverse proxy (Caddy)
  6. Service worker version must be bumped when cache behavior changes
  7. Modal UX keyboard shortcuts (already documented)

What's worth adding to CLAUDE.md:

  • Service worker cache versioning (when to bump)
  • Query parameter handling for SPA-style URLs
  • WebAssembly requirement and detection

What can be removed/simplified:

  • The "Critical: SQLite Dependency" section is gone (no more SQLite)
  • Some details about module organization could be more concise

Let me draft a succinct update.

Good call! Let me review CLAUDE.md and propose updates:

ðŸ‘¤ USER â€” 2025-10-22 15:00:06

Working Dir: /Users/zellyn/gh/trifle

Result:

     1â†’# Trifle - Project Context for Claude
     2â†’
     3â†’## What This Is
     4â†’Local-first browser-based Python3 playground using Pyodide (WASM). All code execution happens client-side. Optional Google OAuth for syncing data to server.
     5â†’
     6â†’## Current Status
     7â†’**Completed:**
     8â†’- âœ… IndexedDB storage layer (client-side)
     9â†’- âœ… Service worker for offline support
    10â†’- âœ… Pyodide integration with web worker execution
    11â†’- âœ… Multi-file editor with auto-save
    12â†’- âœ… ANSI terminal output support
    13â†’- âœ… `input()` support for interactive programs
    14â†’- âœ… Google OAuth authentication (optional, for sync)
    15â†’- âœ… Bidirectional sync with file-based KV store
    16â†’- âœ… Profile management with random name generation
    17â†’
    18â†’**Run locally:**
    19â†’```bash
    20â†’export GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID="$(op read 'op://Shared/Trifle/Google OAuth Client ID')"
    21â†’export GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET="$(op read 'op://Shared/Trifle/Google OAuth Client Secret')"
    22â†’go run main.go  # â†’ http://localhost:3000
    23â†’```
    24â†’
    25â†’**Key decisions:**
    26â†’- **Local-first**: All data in browser IndexedDB, no account required
    27â†’- **Optional sync**: Google OAuth only needed for backup/restore
    28â†’- **Pure KV store**: Server never parses user data, just stores opaque bytes
    29â†’- **Content-addressed storage**: Files stored by SHA-256 hash for deduplication
    30â†’- **Logical clocks**: Conflict resolution for bidirectional sync
    31â†’- **SameSite=Lax** (not Strict) for OAuth callback compatibility
    32â†’- **Production detection**: Inferred from OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL scheme (https = secure cookies)
    33â†’- Client-side execution = **works offline** (after initial load)
    34â†’- Graceful offline handling (service worker shows "Offline" page)
    35â†’
    36â†’## Module Organization
    37â†’- `internal/auth/` - Google OAuth, sessions (email-based, no DB)
    38â†’- `internal/kv/` - File-based key-value store for sync
    39â†’- `web/` - Static frontend (Ace editor, Pyodide, vanilla JS)
    40â†’  - `js/app.js` - Main app controller, trifle list, modals
    41â†’  - `js/db.js` - IndexedDB storage layer with content addressing
    42â†’  - `js/editor.js` - File tree, auto-save, Pyodide execution, `input()` support, ANSI color parsing
    43â†’  - `js/sync-kv.js` - Bidirectional sync manager
    44â†’  - `js/namegen.js` - Client-side random name generator
    45â†’  - `sw.js` - Service worker for offline support
    46â†’
    47â†’## Python Features
    48â†’
    49â†’**`input()` Support**: Terminal-style input directly in the console (like real Python REPL)
    50â†’- Type appears in the console as you enter it
    51â†’- Press Enter to submit
    52â†’- Works for classroom scenarios (guess-the-number, interactive programs, etc.)
    53â†’```python
    54â†’name = input("What's your name? ")
    55â†’print(f"Hello, {name}!")
    56â†’```
    57â†’
    58â†’**ANSI Color Codes**: Full support for terminal colors and backgrounds
    59â†’```python
    60â†’print('\x1b[31mRed text\x1b[0m')
    61â†’print('\x1b[32;40mGreen on black\x1b[0m')
    62â†’```
    63â†’
    64â†’Supported codes: 30-37 (foreground), 40-47 (background), 49 (bg default), 0 (reset)
    65â†’
    66â†’## Editor Shortcuts
    67â†’
    68â†’- **Cmd+Enter** (Mac) / **Ctrl+Enter** (Windows/Linux) - Run code
    69â†’- Auto-save after 1 second of typing inactivity
    70â†’
    71â†’## Modal UX
    72â†’
    73â†’New Trifle modal:
    74â†’- Auto-focuses title field
    75â†’- **Cmd/Ctrl+Enter** to submit
    76â†’- **Esc** to cancel
    77â†’
    78â†’## Workflow
    79â†’
    80â†’**Before committing**: Always use Task tool to launch a code review agent to check for issues.
    81â†’
    82â†’## KV Sync Schema
    83â†’
    84â†’Server stores user data in flat files:
    85â†’```
    86â†’data/
    87â†’â”œâ”€â”€ user/{email}/profile                              # User profile JSON
    88â†’â”œâ”€â”€ user/{email}/trifle/latest/{trifle_id}/{version}  # Latest version pointer (empty file)
    89â†’â”œâ”€â”€ user/{email}/trifle/version/{version}             # Version metadata with file refs
    90â†’â””â”€â”€ file/{hash[0:2]}/{hash[2:4]}/{hash}               # Content-addressed files (global)
    91â†’```
    92â†’
    93â†’- Email-based access control (user can only access their own data)
    94â†’- `file/*` is global (content-addressed, anyone can read/write)
    95â†’- Version ID = `version_{hash[0:16]}`
    96â†’
    97â†’---
    98â†’
    99â†’**IMPORTANT FOR CLAUDE**: When you notice information in conversations that either:
   100â†’1. Contradicts something in this file, OR
   101â†’2. Seems important enough to add (architectural decisions, gotchas, invariants)
   102â†’
   103â†’â†’ Start a conversation with the user about updating CLAUDE.md. Keep it high-value and succinct.
   104â†’

ðŸ¤– ASSISTANT â€” 2025-10-22 15:00:26

{
  "file_path": "/Users/zellyn/gh/trifle/CLAUDE.md",
  "content": "# Trifle - Project Context for Claude\n\n## What This Is\nLocal-first Python3 playground using Pyodide (WASM). All execution client-side. Optional Google OAuth for sync.\n\n## Architecture\n- **Local-first**: All data in browser IndexedDB, no account required\n- **Optional sync**: OAuth only for backup/restore to file-based KV store\n- **Content-addressed**: Files stored by SHA-256, deduplicated\n- **Offline-capable**: Service worker caches app, works without network\n- **WebAssembly required**: Editor checks and shows helpful error if unavailable\n\n## Key Decisions\n- Pure KV store: server never parses user data\n- Logical clocks: conflict resolution for bidirectional sync\n- Email-based auth: no user IDs, email is identity\n- SameSite=Lax: for OAuth callback compatibility\n- Production mode: inferred from OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL scheme (https = secure cookies)\n- Reverse proxy friendly: designed for Caddy/nginx TLS termination\n\n## Module Organization\n- `internal/auth/` - OAuth, sessions (email-based)\n- `internal/kv/` - File-based KV store for sync\n- `web/js/` - app.js (list), db.js (IndexedDB), editor.js (Ace+Pyodide), sync-kv.js, namegen.js\n- `web/sw.js` - Service worker (**bump version** when cache behavior changes)\n\n## Service Worker\n- Caches static files and CDN resources (Pyodide, Ace)\n- Query params: strips them for cache matching (e.g., `/editor.html?id=xyz` \u2192 `/editor.html`)\n- Never caches `/api/*` endpoints\n- Version format: `v{number}` - increment when changing cache logic\n\n## Python Features\n- `input()` with terminal-style prompt\n- ANSI color codes (30-37 fg, 40-47 bg, 0 reset)\n- Web worker execution (non-blocking)\n\n## KV Sync Schema\n```\ndata/\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 user/{email}/profile                              # Profile JSON\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 user/{email}/trifle/latest/{trifle_id}/{version}  # Pointer (empty)\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 user/{email}/trifle/version/{version}             # Metadata + file refs\n\u2514\u2500\u2500 file/{hash[0:2]}/{hash[2:4]}/{hash}               # Global, content-addressed\n```\n- Email-based access control\n- `file/*` is public (content-addressed)\n- Version ID = `version_{hash[0:16]}`\n\n## Shortcuts\n- **Cmd/Ctrl+Enter**: Run code\n- **Cmd/Ctrl+Enter** in modal: Submit\n- **Esc** in modal: Cancel\n- Auto-save after 1s idle\n\n## Run Locally\n```bash\nexport GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID=\"$(op read 'op://Shared/Trifle/Google OAuth Client ID')\"\nexport GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET=\"$(op read 'op://Shared/Trifle/Google OAuth Client Secret')\"\ngo run main.go  # \u2192 http://localhost:3000\n```\n\n## Workflow\nBefore committing: Use Task tool to launch code review agent.\n\n---\n\n**For Claude**: Update this file when you notice contradictions or important architectural decisions.\n"
}

     1â†’# Trifle - Project Context for Claude
     2â†’
     3â†’## What This Is
     4â†’Local-first Python3 playground using Pyodide (WASM). All execution client-side. Optional Google OAuth for sync.
     5â†’
     6â†’## Architecture
     7â†’- **Local-first**: All data in browser IndexedDB, no account required
     8â†’- **Optional sync**: OAuth only for backup/restore to file-based KV store
     9â†’- **Content-addressed**: Files stored by SHA-256, deduplicated
    10â†’- **Offline-capable**: Service worker caches app, works without network
    11â†’- **WebAssembly required**: Editor checks and shows helpful error if unavailable
    12â†’
    13â†’## Key Decisions
    14â†’- Pure KV store: server never parses user data
    15â†’- Logical clocks: conflict resolution for bidirectional sync
    16â†’- Email-based auth: no user IDs, email is identity
    17â†’- SameSite=Lax: for OAuth callback compatibility
    18â†’- Production mode: inferred from OAUTH_REDIRECT_URL scheme (https = secure cookies)
    19â†’- Reverse proxy friendly: designed for Caddy/nginx TLS termination
    20â†’
    21â†’## Module Organization
    22â†’- `internal/auth/` - OAuth, sessions (email-based)
    23â†’- `internal/kv/` - File-based KV store for sync
    24â†’- `web/js/` - app.js (list), db.js (IndexedDB), editor.js (Ace+Pyodide), sync-kv.js, namegen.js
    25â†’- `web/sw.js` - Service worker (**bump version** when cache behavior changes)
    26â†’
    27â†’## Service Worker
    28â†’- Caches static files and CDN resources (Pyodide, Ace)
    29â†’- Query params: strips them for cache matching (e.g., `/editor.html?id=xyz` â†’ `/editor.html`)
    30â†’- Never caches `/api/*` endpoints
    31â†’- Version format: `v{number}` - increment when changing cache logic
    32â†’
    33â†’## Python Features
    34â†’- `input()` with terminal-style prompt
    35â†’- ANSI color codes (30-37 fg, 40-47 bg, 0 reset)
    36â†’- Web worker execution (non-blocking)
    37â†’
    38â†’## KV Sync Schema
    39â†’```
    40â†’data/
    41â†’â”œâ”€â”€ user/{email}/profile                              # Profile JSON
    42â†’â”œâ”€â”€ user/{email}/trifle/latest/{trifle_id}/{version}  # Pointer (empty)
    43â†’â”œâ”€â”€ user/{email}/trifle/version/{version}             # Metadata + file refs
    44â†’â””â”€â”€ file/{hash[0:2]}/{hash[2:4]}/{hash}               # Global, content-addressed
    45â†’```
    46â†’- Email-based access control
    47â†’- `file/*` is public (content-addressed)
    48â†’- Version ID = `version_{hash[0:16]}`
    49â†’
    50â†’## Shortcuts
    51â†’- **Cmd/Ctrl+Enter**: Run code
    52â†’- **Cmd/Ctrl+Enter** in modal: Submit
    53â†’- **Esc** in modal: Cancel
    54â†’- Auto-save after 1s idle
    55â†’
    56â†’## Run Locally
    57â†’```bash
    58â†’export GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID="$(op read 'op://Shared/Trifle/Google OAuth Client ID')"
    59â†’export GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET="$(op read 'op://Shared/Trifle/Google OAuth Client Secret')"
    60â†’go run main.go  # â†’ http://localhost:3000
    61â†’```
